awd_titl_txt: Creating a Data Quality Control Framework for Producing New Personnel-Based S&E Indicators
awd_abstract_narration:
Science and Engineering (S&E) research generates substantial returns in terms of human knowledge, social and economic benefits. Nations around the globe compete for scientific and technological leadership through substantial research funding and focused efforts to develop highly trained workforces. To date, efforts to measure and understand national and international trends in S&E and to assess global strengths and weaknesses, have largely relied on the analysis of documents such as patents and publications using big, growing datasets.  But this approach too often misses or mistakenly identifies the people and teams who do productive science and engineering work. Robust indicators of the size, composition, collaboration, and mobility of the S&E workforce within and across nations are largely missing from analysis and reporting. These key aspects of the national and international scientific enterprise are poorly captured by data analysis focused on documents and citations. To address this problem, this project develops person level workforce and collaboration measures that could add granularity to comparisons of international S&E competitiveness and lead to new policy insights for S&E workforce training, hiring, and retention for a nation's future. 

The prerequisite of such person level indicators is that individual researchers who appear in multiple bibliographic datasets are correctly identified and linked. Effective identification and linkage of authors based on their names is daunting because names are often ambiguous. This is particularly the case for Asian names, which poses a significant problem as Asian researchers play an increasingly important role in many fields of research. This project addresses the challenge of systematically and routinely disambiguating names in big bibliographic datasets using a new Automated and Stratified Entity Disambiguation framework. Core datasets for this effort are derived using a new method that relies on multiple data fields and an iterative process to automatically create disambiguated datasets that can be used to train artificial intelligence tools to conduct robust person level analysis. To improve disambiguation accuracy, name instances are stratified into two groups according to name-ethnicity and disambiguated separately to produce optimal models learned on the automatically generated truth data. Based on the disambiguated data, this project develops new person-level S&E indicators that characterize the landscape and trends of the international S&E research workforce across all science and engineering fields. The new big data tools for automatic disambiguation at scale will be documented and released publicly to enable expansion, validation, and reuse by the science community as well as science of science policy researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
cience and Engineering (S&E) research generates substantial returns in terms of human knowledge, social and economic benefits. Nations around the globe compete for scientific and technological leadership through substantial research funding and focused efforts to develop highly trained workforces. To date, efforts to measure and understand national and international trends in S&E and to assess global strengths and weaknesses, have largely relied on the analysis of documents such as patents and publications using big, growing datasets.  But this approach too often misses or mistakenly identifies the people and teams who do productive science and engineering work. Robust indicators of the size, composition, collaboration, and mobility of the S&E workforce within and across nations are largely missing from analysis and reporting. These key aspects of the national and international scientific enterprise are poorly captured by data analysis focused on documents and citations. One of the biggest challenges for us to address this problem is that author names in publication records are ambiguous: same names can refer to different authors, while different names can refer to the same author. A dominant practice in research and data services using bibliographic data (publication records) is to ignore this problem or conduct inaccurate heuristic disambiguation by deciding author entities based on matching name strings. 

To address this issue, this project developed a computational framework called ASED (Automated and Stratified Entity Disambiguation) to distinguish ‘Who’s Who’ in publication records (name disambiguation) using machine learning trained and evaluated on large scale labeled data. Specifically, our framework partitions ambiguous name instances into different ethnic name groups such as Chinese, English, Indian, Korean, and Hispanic. Then, we train machine learning algorithms based on large-scale labeled data in which millions of name instances are assigned unique author identifiers through linkage to an open author profile database, ORCID, and triangulation of features indicative of author entities. These large-scale labeled data allow us to obtain training samples of name instances necessary to train machine learning models to learn name disambiguation patterns distinct to each ethnic name group. Our project has shown that this ASED framework can produce highly accurate disambiguation results for  a variety of massive bibliographic datasets without much cost of hiring a large group of human coders who are otherwise indispensable for such a large-scale disambiguation task. A tool that implements the machine learning procedure of the ASED is publicly available for validation, reuse, and improvement. This project also demonstrated that using the bibliographic data disambiguated by the ASED framework, we can characterize the composition of research workforce and their collaboration patterns with granularity which was impossible in previous studies that analyze research activity at a document level. Furthermore, this project showcased how the same bibliographic data can produce different findings depending on the choices of author name disambiguation methods, increasing the awareness of scholars about the importance of data quality control in studies mining big data. Scientific knowledge and metrics on scholarly performance and evaluation are used for research modeling and policy making on education, training, and investments in science and engineering. By providing a cost-efficient, accurate framework for researcher disambiguation and thereby producing bibliographic data where researchers are accurately identified, this project contributes to the shaping the policies and investments in science and the education of science workforce, which can affect the competitiveness and future of the U.S.
